WSC-Category 1 Collaborative Proposal: Coupled Multi-scale Economic, Hydrologic, and Estuarine Modeling to Assess Impacts of Climate Change on Water Quality Management

One of the most important questions facing our society is the potential impact of climate change on water quality, water resources and ecosystem function. Confounding issues such as urban sprawl and agricultural intensification make it difficult to determine the singular effects of climate change on water quality, ecosystem function and on the costs to achieve water quality goals. In view of the challenges facing the Chesapeake Bay (urban growth, agricultural intensification, climate change) an integrated multi-disciplinary approach is critical to provide policy makers with robust and reliable information. The approach that the research team will use is to integrate key climate, hydrologic, estuarine, and economic drivers at multiple scales which will provide water management options for the Chesapeake Bay system.

One way to assess the impacts of climate change in the face of these other stressors is to develop coupled models that incorporate the pertinent controls on the water system. The overarching goal of this project is to develop a quantifiable, predictive framework that couples biogeochemical and hydrologic drivers of terrestrial nutrient export with climate change to evaluate the effects of ecosystem management on estuarine function and costs of water quality protection. To achieve this goal, the project proposes to work broadly across common regional Chesapeake Bay watershed physiographic gradients and dominant land uses (e.g., agriculture, forest and urban) using a multi-scale model evaluation of the impact of climate change and climate variability on the hydrologic, biogeochemical, and economic drivers of water quality degradation in the Chesapeake Bay estuary. Climate data will be down scaled from global and regional climate models and applied to watershed models to predict hydrologic activity and nutrient production across five test-bed watersheds where significant investments in land management (e.g., Best Management Practices) have been made. Test-bed model results will be used to populate an economic model to quantify the optimum tradeoff between water quality improvements and their associated costs. The watershed models will then be upscaled to predict hydrologic and nutrient delivery to an estuarine model to determine estuary impacts.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most important questions facing our society is the potential impact of climate change on water quality, water resources and ecosystem function. Confounding issues such as urban sprawl and agricultural intensification make it difficult to determine the singular effects of climate change on water quality, ecosystem function and on the costs to achieve water quality goals. One way to assess the impacts of climate change in the face of these other stressors is to develop coupled models that incorporate the pertinent controls on the water system. The overarching goal of this project is to develop a quantifiable, predictive framework that couples biogeochemical and hydrologic drivers of terrestrial nutrient export with climate change to evaluate the effects of ecosystem management on estuarine function and costs of water quality protection. To achieve this goal, the team at the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, in collaborations with scientists at Virginia Institute of Technology and Pennsylvania State University, developed a coupled hydrodynamic-biogeochemical model for the Chesapeake Bay and used it to investigate how past climate variability and future climate change affect hypoxia in the estuary. Although nutrient loading to Chesapeake Bay has been stabilized in recent years, seasonal hypoxia persists and displays large year-to-year variations, with larger hypoxic volumes in wetter years and smaller hypoxic volumes in drier years. Data analysis points to climate as a driver of interannual hypoxia variability, but nutrient inputs covary with freshwater flow. We conducted an oxygen budget analysis of Chesapeake Bay to quantify relative contributions of physical and biogeochemical processes. Vertical diffusive flux declines with river discharge, whereas longitudinal advective flux increases with river discharge, such that the total physical supply of oxygen to bottom water is relatively unchanged. However, water column respiration due to biological processes exhibits large interannual fluctuations and is correlated with primary production and hypoxic volume. Hence, our model results suggest that nutrient loading is the main mechanism driving interannual hypoxia variability in Chesapeake Bay over the past couple of decades. This has implications for developing appropriate nutrient management strategies in a changing climate and suggests that continued nutrient reduction would be needed to reduce hypoxia and its impacts on marine ecosystems. To project the impact of future climate change on hypoxia in Chesapeake Bay, we simulated changes in dissolved oxygen between late 20th century and mid-21st century using the coupled hydrodynamic-biogeochemical model forced by multiple bias-corrected downscaled regional climate models in North America. The model predicts strong declines in the oxygen concentration and large increases (~20-40%) in the summer hypoxic and anoxic volumes in the future climate. An analysis of the dissolved oxygen budget in the bottom water reveals that decreasing physical supply of oxygen to the bottom water is the main cause for the loss of dissolved oxygen during the summer, while decreasing O2 solubility only has a minor effect. With this large expansion of estuarine hypoxia projected for the mid-21st century, stronger nutrient reduction efforts would be required in order to constrain the hypoxia under the current management target.
